Problem:
In a control system, the output \( z(t) \) is governed by the linear time-invariant system represented by the Laplace Transform \( Z(s) = H(s)X(s) \), where \( H(s) \) is the transfer function and \( X(s) \) is the input in the s-domain. Consider the effect of an additive control intervention \( u(t) \) on the system, represented in the Laplace domain by \( U(s) \). The modified system output is \( Y(s) = H(s)(X(s) + U(s)) \).

Given the output \( Y(s) \) at some time \( T \), can we distinguish whether the input was altered by \( U(s) \), only knowing \( Y(s) \) and \( H(s) \)?
Explanation: The information \( Y(s) \) alone, without additional constraints or knowledge about \( U(s) \), does not uniquely determine whether an intervention has occurred. Multiple combinations of \( X(s) \) and \( U(s) \) could lead to the same \( Y(s) \) due to the linear properties of the system.
